description: From Middle English remaindre, remeigner, from Anglo-Norman remaindre, with infinitive used as noun.

entries.meaning: A part or parts remaining after some has/have been removed.
examples: My son ate part of his cake and I ate the remainder.
You can have the remainder of my clothes.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) The amount left over after subtracting the divisor as many times as possible from the dividend without producing a negative result. If n (dividend) and d (divisor) are integers, then n can always be expressed in the form n = dq + r, where q (quotient) and r (remainder) are also integers and 0 â‰¤ r < d.
examples: 17 leaves a remainder of 2 when divided by 3.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) The number left over after a simple subtraction
(commerce) Excess stock items left unsold and subject to reduction in price.
examples: I got a really good price on this shirt because it was a remainder.

entries.meaning: (law) An estate in expectancy which only comes in its heir's possession after an estate created by the same instrument has been determined

verbs.description: remainder (third-person singular simple present remainders, present participle remaindering, simple past and past participle remaindered)

entries.meaning: (transitive, commerce) To mark or declare items left unsold as subject to reduction in price.
examples: The bookstore remaindered the unsold copies of that book at the end of summer.
